items.title:
One Markdown file + Claude is all you need for productivity.

I've been doing this for a couple of y...
items.content:
One Markdown file + Claude is all you need for productivity.

I've been doing this for a couple of years. I started without using a large language model, but now this is 10x better than before.

Here is what I do:

1. I have a never-ending markdown file
2. Every day, I add a new date at the top
3. I write down tasks that I check off when done
4. I write down ideas, thoughts, and anything that matters

The file is just a continuous stream of tasks, thoughts, ideas, notes, and reminders.

There are no rules on what to write and how to do it, especially now that you can load this file with Claude and ask anything.

I have the file stored in an iCloud-backed folder, so it synchronizes with all my devices.

When I started, I was much stricter about the format because I needed a way to search for specific information.

Now, anything works.

For example, I can ask Claude to give me a list of things I want to do, the list of restaurants I visited last month, or to explain my mood last week based on the thoughts I wrote.

Pretty frigging cool.

This requires no setup. It's free to use. You can use any model, free or paid. There's no pressure to keep a specific format or obligation to follow any rules.

Give it a try.

items.summary: Detailed productivity system using a single Markdown file + Claude for task tracking, ideas, and memory. File syncs via iCloud, Claude enables natural language queries over personal history.

items.title:
Two videos give state of art of XR at #ces2026. This is my ninth and 10th video report from CES. 

B...
items.content:
Two videos give state of art of XR at #ces2026. This is my ninth and 10th video report from CES. 

Both were in suites, which means the public couldn't get into see them. 

The first is of @getVITURE, which had the best middle-weight AI glasses. 

The second is of @LumusVision, which makes the glass in the displays of the Meta Rayban Displays (the industry calls them waveguides). It showed me the first that I've seen that have 70 degree field of view. Meta's current glasses have waveguides that can only do about 20 degree field of view. The difference in size of the virtual image you see in front of you is like going from an iPhone to a 100-inch TV on your wall.

The Viture, along with competitors, @rayneo_global, @RokidGlobal, @XREAL_Global, among others, use a hybrid waveguide and bird bath optic. The bird bath has a much thicker optic in front of your eyes. 

If you actually want to play a video game, or work while say on a flight, the middle weights are the ones you want. The virtual image is like seeing a movie in a movie theater. 

The problems with the bird bath optics are they aren't good to wear in the real world, like while walking around a shopping mall, and need to be plugged into a phone or a laptop to save weight and have enough processing power to put a movie up in front of you. 

That takes us to lightweights. I saw many, and Lumus' 70-degree field of view waveguide will be in lightweights in 2028. And I assume there are competitors that we'll probably see at SPIE (optics show in San Francisco) in a few months. Many of the lightweights, like @EvenRealities, have small green and black displays. I have them and they are quite nice, but I want full color displays for obvious reasons. 

Apple bought a waveguide company years ago, so I assume it is working on some in secret, plus its partner, @ZEISS_Group, showed off waveguides years ago at CES, and since that's the biggest optics company in the world, it is an easy assumption to say that Zeiss is working on the displays that Apple will use.

Elsewhere in the suites, @Goertek_USA was showing off a new "heavyweight" with 4k displays, think of an Apple Vision Pro. Except it was only about 100 grams. Reference design, so not in real products yet. 

But all this points to that every year from now on we'll see a lot more displays on people's faces.

At XReal they told me their Holodeck glasses are coming later this year.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Comprehensive CES 2026 report on XR/AI glasses: covers Viture, Lumus waveguides with 70¬∞ FOV (vs Meta's 20¬∞), comparison of middleware vs lightweight glasses, and industry roadmap through 2028
items.reasoning: Detailed original industry analysis from established tech journalist, covers AI glasses ecosystem including Meta partnership, provides technical specifications and timeline predictions, very high engagement (29K views)

items.title: An absolutely right decision. Claude models were fine-tuned with reinforcement learning to work with...
items.content:
An absolutely right decision. Claude models were fine-tuned with reinforcement learning to work with a specific interface. This is why Claude is so effective in coding.

When you withdraw the model that was finetuned to work in a certain environment and put it into a different one, the consequences are absolutely unpredictable. Furthermore, the user experience is arbitrarily worse compared to the UX with the environment for which the model was finetuned.

I'm 100% certain that people who still claim that Gemini is better for coding than Claude used Claude in a non-native environment.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Claude models fine-tuned for specific interface via RL - using them in non-native environments produces worse results. Claims Gemini vs Claude coding comparisons flawed by environment mismatch
items.reasoning: Technical insight about model fine-tuning and evaluation methodology, high engagement, relevant to model comparison debates

items.title: Every LLM supports structured outputs, but they struggle extracting *a lot* info from massive compli...
items.content:
Every LLM supports structured outputs, but they struggle extracting *a lot* info from massive complicated documents. Especially in a zero-shot, 100% accurate manner.

We‚Äôve created a new tutorial to help you do zero-shot extraction of massively repeating structured outputs from complex docs.

For instance, maybe you have a file of 100 resumes, and you want to extract out candidate info for each candidate. Or you have an entire collection of financial statements.

In these cases, you want a multi-step agentic workflow that can detect document boundaries ‚úÇÔ∏è, intelligently extract subsets of outputs from subsets of documents üìù, and stitch them together üßµ

This makes use of our LlamaSplit capability to split docs into relevant ‚Äúsub-chunks‚Äù and LlamaExtract to extract consistent structured outputs from each chunk.

https://t.co/bUgkVaDM7F
items.author: @jerryjliu0
items.summary: Jerry Liu introduces LlamaIndex tutorial for zero-shot extraction of structured outputs from complex documents using LlamaSplit and LlamaExtract
items.reasoning: LlamaIndex founder sharing technical tutorial for handling structured extraction at scale. Addresses real enterprise use case with multi-step agentic workflow.

items.title: @UziCryptoo Yeah, I've noticed this quite a bit over the last year, and it's getting worse for certa...
items.content:
@UziCryptoo Yeah, I've noticed this quite a bit over the last year, and it's getting worse for certain kinds of content producers. It's like somebody at X has already decided, "Oh, Scoble should only get seen 50,000 times today." If you start spreading yourself over everyone's posts‚Äîresharing and commenting a lot‚Äîit won't give you more than those 50,000 views. Instead, it splits that 50,000 up into little bites.

Because of this, there's some pressure to slow down your posting pace:
1. Only post once, or perhaps one to three times
2. Limit yourself to five or ten comments, rather than 200

They're trying to knock down spam, which is a good thing, but this changes the service to be much more news-focused rather than "yakety-yak" focused. I'm still out to lunch on whether this is a good or bad thing. There are certainly benefits; my feed has been way more interesting lately. 

However, I'm seeing a lot of complaints from people saying they can't get seen anymore. I could certainly make those complaints too; even with 500,000 followers, I am certainly not having everyone see my posts. items.title: I think the biggest issue if you do something and write a book about it, then people who read it wil...
items.content:
I think the biggest issue if you do something and write a book about it, then people who read it will try to exactly copy what you did, but  the moment you write something (at least iin tech), it's already outdated, because things change so fast

So if you read a book you gotta kinda think like "okay this used to work, probably not anymore, but I have to figure out the philosophy behind it" and then if you can do that you can put your own spin to it and get successful

items.title:
@DarwinianVyas > you have to read something that reads like a blog article

That was my goal. I didn...
items.content:
@DarwinianVyas > you have to read something that reads like a blog article

That was my goal. I didn't know it might annoy someone.

PDFs have a rigid pixel-based structure designed for printing and hard to work with otherwise. Even copy-pasting from PDF is a nightmare. Adding any logic on top of it is nightmare squared.

Markdown is flexible and supports math, so I'm wondering why scientists still support this ugly Adobe-made format instead of staying in text, or at least LaTeX, all the time.
items.author: @burkov
items.reasoning: Not analyzed (batch processing)

items.title: @DarwinianVyas PDF isn't done for this kind of usage. In a PDF, there' no notion of formatted text, ...
items.content: @DarwinianVyas PDF isn't done for this kind of usage. In a PDF, there' no notion of formatted text, figures, or tables, at all. It's all pixels and/or vectors. So, if you want to reveal by sentence or paragraph, you need to convert a PDF into some text-based format. I use Markdown.
items.author: @burkov
items.summary: Explaining PDF structure limitations for text extraction and need for Markdown conversion
items.reasoning: Technical context for document processing challenges

items.title: @DarwinianVyas When a PDF is created from LaTeX, the original LaTeX source is no longer available in...
items.content: @DarwinianVyas When a PDF is created from LaTeX, the original LaTeX source is no longer available in the PDF file. The PDF contains a text layer where equations are represented with plain text characters, making them unreadable. I have a LaTeX to Markdown converter that I use for converting arXiv papers, but it's not production-ready yet to my taste, so I haven't deployed it. However, it will be available soon in paid plans.

items.title:
For some reason I see A LOT of masculinized women faces when I visit Brazil

There's something speci...
items.content:
For some reason I see A LOT of masculinized women faces when I visit Brazil

There's something specific going on there where women are having surgery to get a masculine jawline, because most Brazilian influencer women kinda look like this and it's horrid

I feel it's like they are trying to impress/attract/signal to other women instead of men, which isn't great

Why this specifically happens more in Brazil than in for US where there's also lots of plastic surgery, I wonder a lot

"The travestization of the feminine is a psyop that has been happening for more than ten years. One of its milestones was the moment when gay makeup artists began to occupy the place of aesthetic authority over what would be the ‚Äúfeminine beauty,‚Äù ceasing to interpret femininity to, little by little, prescribe it. 

The result of this turning point was a feminine aesthetic that is increasingly artificial, hyperconstructed, and standardized, guided by exaggerated, angular, and performative traits, often dissociated from concrete female corporeality. 

That‚Äôs why nowadays many surgeries and procedures no longer aim to enhance the feminine, but rather to replace it with a technical caricature, an imitation of traits that were born outside of the feminine experience itself.

Very sad."

items.title: More than 12,000 people are arrested in the UK every year for online comments. The arrests are based...
items.content:
More than 12,000 people are arrested in the UK every year for online comments. The arrests are based on the so-called hate speech accusations.

The defenders of these arrests say that these comments often contain threats of violence against some groups of people, and they say that the principle is the same as if you made comments offline in a public space.

The difference is actually colossal. We have only one planet, and in the city we live, there is a limited number of public spaces one cannot avoid if they want to be able to leave home.

Online, on the other hand, there's an infinity of public places. If you think that in some places they can talk to you in a way you don't like or threaten you, just DON'T FUCKING GO to such online places.

There's no lack of online places where no one will physically be able to threaten you. There's actually an infinity of such places.

But you, for some reason, decide to go to places where they post stuff offensive to you. Are you a masochist?

No, there's no equivalence between online and offline. Anyone claiming there is, is either an illiterate retard or a left-wing manipulator (but likely both).

items.summary: Political commentary on UK online speech arrests
